source_textbook: Using Claude Skills to Create Intelligent Textbooks

questions.question: What is this course about?
questions.answer: This course provides comprehensive training on leveraging Claude Skills to create intelligent, interactive textbooks that enhance learning through AI-assisted content generation. You'll learn the complete workflow from course conception through deployment, including creating learning graphs, generating glossaries, building interactive simulations (MicroSims), and publishing professional educational materials using MkDocs with the Material theme. The course emphasizes practical, hands-on skills for educators, instructional designers, and content creators who want to harness the power of AI to produce high-quality educational materials efficiently.

questions.question: Who is this course for?
questions.answer: This course is designed for professional development and targets educators, instructional designers, technical writers, and content creators who want to use AI tools to build intelligent textbooks. You should have a basic understanding of programming, familiarity with prompt engineering concepts, access to Anthropic Claude, and curiosity about using AI to build textbooks. While technical background is helpful, the course focuses on practical skills rather than deep programming knowledge.

questions.question: What are the prerequisites for this course?
questions.answer: Before starting this course, you should have: basic programming understanding (familiarity with concepts like variables, functions, and control flow), prompt engineering basics (understanding how to write effective prompts for AI systems), Anthropic Claude access (an active Claude Pro account for extended usage limits), and curiosity and motivation (willingness to explore AI-assisted educational content creation).

questions.question: How do I install Claude Skills on my computer?
questions.answer: Installing Claude Skills involves two steps: First, clone the repository using 'git clone https://github.com/dmccreary/claude-skills.git' to download the skills. Second, run the installation script by navigating to the 'scripts/' directory and running './install-claude-skills.sh'. This creates symbolic links from your '~/.claude/skills/' directory to the cloned skills, making them available across all your projects. For project-specific installation, modify the script to point to your project's '.claude/skills/' directory instead.

questions.question: What will I be able to do after completing this course?
questions.answer: After completing this course, you'll be able to: create intelligent textbooks from scratch using Claude Skills and MkDocs, generate learning graphs with 200+ concepts and dependency relationships, build interactive simulations (MicroSims) using p5.js for educational visualization, automate content generation for chapters, glossaries, FAQs, and quizzes, apply Bloom's Taxonomy to create learning outcomes at all cognitive levels, and publish professional educational materials using GitHub Pages. The capstone project involves designing and implementing a complete intelligent textbook for a subject of your choice, demonstrating mastery of the entire workflow.

questions.question: How long does this course take to complete?
questions.answer: The course consists of 13 chapters covering topics from AI fundamentals to deployment workflows. The time commitment varies based on your background and learning pace, but most learners should expect: 20-30 hours to work through all chapters (core content), 15-25 hours for exercises and skill experimentation (hands-on practice), and 10-20 hours to create a complete intelligent textbook (capstone project). Total estimated time: 45-75 hours for thorough completion including the capstone project. You can work at your own pace, and the modular structure allows you to focus on specific topics as needed.

questions.question: What tools do I need to get started?
questions.answer: To work through this course effectively, you'll need: Claude Pro account (for extended usage limits and access to Claude Code), Visual Studio Code or similar editor (for content development and markdown editing), Git (for version control and content management), Python 3.x (for running learning graph processing scripts and pip for package management), terminal/command-line access (for running shell scripts and commands), and a web browser (for testing MkDocs sites locally and accessing documentation). All tools are free except the Claude Pro subscription.

questions.question: Do I need to know Python or JavaScript?
questions.answer: Not extensively! While the course uses Python scripts for processing learning graphs and JavaScript for creating MicroSims, you don't need to be an expert programmer. For Python, the course provides pre-built scripts (analyze-graph.py, csv-to-json.py, etc.) that you run as-is, and basic understanding of running Python commands is helpful. For JavaScript/p5.js, the microsim-p5 skill generates simulation code for you, and understanding basic JavaScript helps customize simulations, but isn't required for core functionality. The focus is on using these tools through Claude Skills rather than writing code from scratch.

questions.question: How do I list the skills I have installed?
questions.answer: There are two ways to list your installed skills: Ask Claude directly by typing 'What skills do you know about? Check the ~/.claude/skills/ area.' Or use the /skills slash command by installing the custom command with the install-skills-command.sh script, then typing '/skills' in Claude Code. The slash command provides formatted output organized by category, showing all user and project-specific skills.

questions.question: What is the difference between a Claude Skill and a Claude Command?
questions.answer: Claude Skills are autonomous agents with full workflow instructions defined in SKILL.md files. They can use multiple tools, make decisions, and execute complex multi-step processes. Skills are invoked with '/skill [name]' and run specialized workflows like generating learning graphs or creating glossaries. Claude Commands are simpler prompt expansions defined in markdown files. They expand text instructions that Claude then interprets, similar to custom shortcuts. Commands are invoked with '/[name]' and are useful for repetitive prompts.

questions.question: How do I update my skills to the latest version?
questions.answer: Since the skills are installed via symbolic links to a Git repository, updating is simple: Navigate to your cloned repository with 'cd ~/projects/claude-skills', then pull the latest changes with 'git pull'. Skills are automatically updated via symlinks - no need to reinstall or recreate links. The symbolic link structure means any changes in the repository immediately reflect in your '~/.claude/skills/' directory.

questions.question: What is an intelligent textbook?
questions.answer: An intelligent textbook is an educational resource that goes beyond static text and images to provide interactive, adaptive, and AI-enhanced learning experiences. The course framework defines five levels of intelligence: Level 1 (static content), Level 2 (hyperlinked navigation), Level 3 (interactive elements), Level 4 (adaptive content), and Level 5 (AI-powered personalization). This course primarily targets Level 2-3 textbooks using MkDocs Material theme, with support for Level 3 features through MicroSims, quizzes, and interactive elements.

questions.question: What is a learning graph?
questions.answer: A learning graph is a structured representation of knowledge that maps concepts and their prerequisite relationships in a course or subject domain. Each concept is a node, and directed edges represent dependencies (concept A must be learned before concept B). Key characteristics include 200 concepts for comprehensive course coverage, Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) structure with dependencies flowing in one direction with no circular loops, taxonomy categories grouping concepts by theme, and prerequisite tracking ensuring proper learning sequence. Learning graphs serve as roadmaps guiding students through optimal learning pathways.

questions.question: What is a Claude Skill?
questions.answer: A Claude Skill is an autonomous agent defined by a SKILL.md file that automates specific aspects of intelligent textbook creation. Skills contain YAML frontmatter (metadata including name, description, license, and allowed tools), workflow instructions (step-by-step processes Claude executes autonomously), and supporting assets (Python scripts, templates, and reference documentation). Skills are installed in '~/.claude/skills/' and invoked with the Skill tool or '/skill [name]' command.

questions.question: What is Bloom's Taxonomy and why is it important?
questions.answer: Bloom's Taxonomy is an educational framework that classifies learning objectives into six cognitive levels, from basic recall to creative synthesis. The 2001 revision uses these levels: Remember (retrieve, recognize, recall), Understand (construct meaning, explain), Apply (use procedures in new situations), Analyze (break into parts, examine relationships), Evaluate (make judgments based on criteria), and Create (produce original work, design solutions). Well-designed educational content addresses all cognitive levels, ensuring students develop both foundational knowledge and higher-order thinking skills. This course uses Bloom's Taxonomy to structure learning outcomes, quiz questions, and content generation.

questions.question: How does a learning graph guide student learning?
questions.answer: A learning graph provides a visual and structural roadmap that shows learners where to start (foundational concepts with no prerequisites appear first), what comes next (prerequisites must be mastered before advancing to dependent concepts), how concepts connect (understanding relationships deepens comprehension), and alternative pathways (multiple routes may exist through the material). The graph also helps instructors identify knowledge gaps, optimize chapter sequencing, and ensure comprehensive topic coverage. Interactive graph viewers let students explore the concept network visually.

questions.question: What is MkDocs and why use it for textbooks?
questions.answer: MkDocs is a fast, simple static site generator designed for building project documentation from markdown files. With the Material for MkDocs theme, it becomes an excellent platform for intelligent textbooks because it provides clean, responsive design (professional appearance on all devices), navigation features (table of contents, search, breadcrumbs, page navigation), markdown support (easy content authoring with extensions), customization (themes, colors, logos, CSS), and GitHub Pages integration (free hosting and automatic deployment). MkDocs targets Level 2 intelligent textbooks (hyperlinked navigation) with support for Level 3 features through embedded MicroSims and interactive elements.

questions.question: What is a MicroSim?
questions.answer: A MicroSim is a focused, interactive educational simulation built with p5.js that helps students visualize and explore a single concept or relationship. Each MicroSim targets one concept (focused learning objective), provides interactivity (sliders, buttons, and controls for exploration), uses seeded randomness (reproducible results for consistent learning), and embeds in textbooks (iframe integration with documentation). MicroSims are stored in 'docs/sims/[name]/' directories with 'main.html' (the simulation) and 'index.md' (documentation). The microsim-p5 skill automates MicroSim creation.

questions.question: What is ISO 11179 and why does it matter for glossaries?
questions.answer: ISO 11179 is an international standard for metadata registries that defines principles for creating precise, unambiguous term definitions. Glossary definitions following ISO 11179 must be precise (exact meaning without ambiguity), concise (minimal words while conveying full meaning), distinct (clearly differentiated from related terms), non-circular (don't define terms using themselves), and free of business rules (no implementation details or procedures). Following ISO 11179 ensures glossary terms are professional, clear, and useful for learning. The glossary-generator skill automatically creates ISO 11179-compliant definitions.

questions.question: What are the five levels of textbook intelligence?
questions.answer: The five-level intelligence framework classifies textbooks by their interactive and adaptive capabilities: Level 1 (Static Content - traditional PDFs with fixed text and images, no interactivity), Level 2 (Hyperlinked Navigation - HTML/web-based with table of contents, cross-references, and search), Level 3 (Interactive Elements - embedded quizzes, simulations, visualizations, and dynamic content), Level 4 (Adaptive Content - personalization based on learner progress, performance, and preferences), and Level 5 (AI Personalization - intelligent tutoring systems that generate custom content, provide real-time help, and adapt to individual learning styles). This course primarily targets Level 2 with tools for advancing to Level 3.

questions.question: What is the difference between concepts and topics?
questions.answer: Concepts are atomic, indivisible ideas that represent single learning units in a learning graph. Each concept should be granular enough to be taught and assessed independently. Topics are broader themes or subject areas that encompass multiple concepts. Topics often become chapters or sections in textbooks. A single topic might contain 10-20 concepts in the learning graph. When generating learning graphs, focus on identifying atomic concepts rather than broad topics—the learning-graph-generator skill helps with this granularity.

questions.question: What is a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG)?
questions.answer: A Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) is a graph structure where edges have direction (concept A → concept B means A is a prerequisite for B) and no path through the graph returns to a starting node (no circular dependencies). DAGs matter for learning graphs because prerequisites must follow a logical sequence. If Concept A requires Concept B, and Concept B requires Concept C, then Concept C cannot require Concept A (that would create a cycle). The analyze-graph.py script validates DAG structure and detects circular dependencies.

questions.question: What is concept dependency mapping?
questions.answer: Concept dependency mapping is the process of identifying prerequisite relationships between concepts in a learning graph. For each concept, you specify which other concepts must be learned first. Dependencies are encoded in CSV format with pipe-delimited ConceptIDs. Proper dependency mapping ensures logical learning sequences and prevents students from encountering concepts before they have necessary background knowledge.

questions.question: How many concepts should a learning graph have?
questions.answer: The learning-graph-generator skill targets 200 concepts for a comprehensive course, based on educational research suggesting this provides optimal granularity for breadth (covering all major topics and subtopics), depth (atomic concepts that can be individually taught and assessed), and manageability (large enough to be thorough, small enough to comprehend as a whole). You can adjust this number based on course scope: introductory courses (100-150 concepts), comprehensive courses (200-250 concepts), graduate-level courses (250-300 concepts). More concepts provide finer granularity but increase complexity. The key is ensuring each concept is atomic (indivisible) and meaningful as a learning unit.

questions.question: What is taxonomy categorization in learning graphs?
questions.answer: Taxonomy categorization groups related concepts into thematic categories, helping organize and visualize the learning graph. Common categories include FOUND (foundational prerequisites), BASIC (core fundamental concepts), INTER (intermediate topics), ADVNC (advanced concepts), TOOLS (software tools and technologies), and SKILL (practical skills and techniques). Each concept receives a TaxonomyID (3-5 letter abbreviation) in the learning graph CSV. These categories aid visualization (color-coding concepts by category in graph viewers), balance content (ensuring no category is over-represented), and guide organization (informing chapter structure and content progression).

questions.question: What makes a high-quality learning graph?
questions.answer: A high-quality learning graph scores 70+/100 on the quality metrics generated by analyze-graph.py. Key indicators include structure quality (valid DAG with no circular dependencies, no self-dependencies, connected graph with no isolated subgraphs), connectivity quality (foundational concepts with zero dependencies, average 2-4 dependencies per concept, no orphaned nodes), balance quality (taxonomy distribution with no category over 30%, reasonable maximum chain length), and completeness (200 concepts generated, all concepts have labels under 32 characters). The quality report identifies specific issues and recommendations for improvement.

questions.question: What file format is used for learning graphs?
questions.answer: Learning graphs use CSV (Comma-Separated Values) format with four columns: ConceptID (integer 1-200, unique identifier), ConceptLabel (Title Case, max 32 characters, human-readable name), Dependencies (pipe-delimited list of ConceptIDs, empty for foundational concepts), and TaxonomyID (3-5 letter category abbreviation). This format is human-readable, easy to edit in spreadsheet software, and processable by Python scripts. The csv-to-json.py script converts CSV to vis-network JSON for interactive visualization.

questions.question: What Python scripts are used for learning graph processing?
questions.answer: The learning-graph-generator skill includes four main Python scripts in 'docs/learning-graph/': analyze-graph.py (validates DAG structure, detects circular dependencies, calculates quality metrics, generates quality report markdown), csv-to-json.py (converts learning graph CSV to vis-network JSON format for interactive visualization), add-taxonomy.py (adds TaxonomyID column to learning graph CSV if missing), and taxonomy-distribution.py (generates taxonomy distribution report showing concept counts by category). All scripts are run from the 'docs/learning-graph/' directory after the learning graph CSV is generated. They require Python 3.x and standard libraries (no pip packages needed for basic functionality).

questions.question: How do I run the learning graph validation scripts?
questions.answer: After generating a learning graph, navigate to the 'docs/learning-graph/' directory and run: 'python analyze-graph.py learning-graph.csv quality-metrics.md', 'python csv-to-json.py learning-graph.csv learning-graph.json', and 'python taxonomy-distribution.py learning-graph.csv taxonomy-distribution.md'. Expected outputs include quality-metrics.md (quality score, validation results, recommendations), learning-graph.json (vis-network format for interactive graph viewer), and taxonomy-distribution.md (concept count by category with distribution chart). These reports help assess graph quality and identify improvements needed.

questions.question: What is vis-network JSON format?
questions.answer: vis-network is a JavaScript library for interactive graph visualization. The format required by vis-network includes nodes (array of concepts with id, label, and group taxonomy category) and edges (array of dependency relationships with from prerequisite and to dependent concept). The csv-to-json.py script automatically converts learning graph CSV to this format. The vis-network library then renders an interactive, draggable graph with color-coded nodes by taxonomy category.

questions.question: What is YAML frontmatter in skill definitions?
questions.answer: YAML frontmatter is metadata at the beginning of SKILL.md files, enclosed in '---' delimiters, that defines skill properties. Fields include name (skill identifier matching directory name), description (brief explanation of skill purpose), license (software license, typically Apache-2.0 or MIT), and allowed-tools (optional list of Claude Code tools the skill can use). YAML frontmatter is a standard way to add metadata to markdown files, widely used in static site generators and documentation tools.

questions.question: How do I customize MkDocs theme colors?
questions.answer: MkDocs Material theme allows color customization through CSS and configuration. Method 1 uses configuration in mkdocs.yml with palette primary and accent settings. Method 2 uses custom CSS by creating 'docs/css/extra.css' and overriding Material theme variables like --md-primary-fg-color and --md-accent-fg-color, then referencing the custom CSS in mkdocs.yml with extra_css. This course website uses custom CSS to apply Anthropic brand colors (RGB: 218, 120, 87).

questions.question: What markdown extensions does MkDocs Material support?
questions.answer: MkDocs Material supports many useful markdown extensions for educational content: admonition (callout boxes for notes, warnings, tips), pymdownx.details (collapsible sections), pymdownx.superfences (enhanced code blocks with syntax highlighting), pymdownx.tabbed (tabbed content sections), attr_list (add CSS classes and attributes to elements), and md_in_html (use markdown inside HTML blocks). Enable extensions in 'mkdocs.yml' under the markdown_extensions section.

questions.question: How do I embed a MicroSim in a textbook page?
questions.answer: MicroSims are embedded using HTML iframes in markdown files. Each MicroSim has 'main.html' (standalone p5.js simulation in 'docs/sims/[name]/') and 'index.md' (documentation page with iframe embed). The iframe loads the simulation while the surrounding markdown provides context, instructions, and learning objectives. The microsim-p5 skill automatically generates both files with proper structure.

questions.question: What is Dublin Core metadata?
questions.answer: Dublin Core is a standardized set of metadata elements for describing digital resources, widely used in libraries and archives. The 15 core elements include key fields for learning graphs: Title (name of the learning graph), Description (brief explanation of content), Creator (author or institution), Date (creation or modification date), Format (file format like 'text/csv' or 'application/json'), and License (usage rights like 'CC BY 4.0'). Dublin Core metadata appears in the vis-network JSON format for learning graphs, providing standardized documentation. This helps with content discovery, reusability, and academic citation.

questions.question: How do I configure navigation in MkDocs?
questions.answer: Navigation structure is defined in the 'nav:' section of 'mkdocs.yml'. Features include nested structure creating dropdown menus, order determining menu appearance, section names (before colons) appearing in navigation, and file paths relative to 'docs/'. After adding any new markdown file to 'docs/', update the 'nav:' section so it appears in site navigation. MkDocs Material provides breadcrumbs and previous/next navigation automatically.

questions.question: What permissions does Claude Code need for skills?
questions.answer: Claude Code has strict default permissions that prompt for approval on every file read/write. For skill-based textbook development, recommended permissions in '.claude/config.json' include allowing all skill invocations, all bash commands, and reading/writing all files in project directory. Only use permissive settings in Git-tracked projects where changes can be reverted.

questions.question: How do I deploy my textbook to GitHub Pages?
questions.answer: MkDocs makes GitHub Pages deployment simple. One-time setup involves creating a GitHub repository for your textbook, pushing content to main branch, and ensuring 'mkdocs.yml' has correct 'site_url' and 'repo_url'. To deploy, run 'mkdocs gh-deploy'. This builds the site and pushes to the 'gh-pages' branch automatically. GitHub Pages serves the content at 'https://[username].github.io/[repo-name]/'. Continuous deployment can be set up with GitHub Actions to automatically deploy on push to main branch.

questions.question: What is seeded randomness in MicroSims?
questions.answer: Seeded randomness means using a fixed random seed so that 'random' behaviors are reproducible. In p5.js, you use randomSeed(42) in setup() so random() produces the same sequence every time. Benefits for education include reproducibility (students see same visualization on reload), consistency (discussion and documentation reference specific outputs), and debugging (easier to identify and fix issues). MicroSims use seeded randomness by default, with optional controls to change the seed for exploration.

questions.question: Why am I getting circular dependency errors in my learning graph?
questions.answer: Circular dependencies occur when concept prerequisites form a cycle, making it impossible to determine learning order. Common causes include reciprocal dependencies (Concept A depends on B, and B depends on A), indirect cycles (A → B → C → A creates a longer cycle), and self-dependencies (a concept listed as its own prerequisite). To fix, run 'analyze-graph.py' to identify the cycle, review the concepts in the cycle to determine true prerequisite relationships, break the cycle by removing or reordering one dependency, and consider splitting overly broad concepts into smaller atomic units.

questions.question: My learning graph has orphaned nodes. What does this mean?
questions.answer: Orphaned nodes are concepts that nothing depends on—they're terminal leaves with no outgoing edges. While not errors, many orphaned nodes suggest missing dependencies (later concepts should build on these but don't), over-granularity (concepts too specific to be prerequisites), or incomplete graph (advanced topics not yet added). To fix, review the quality metrics report for the list of orphaned nodes, identify which concepts should logically depend on these orphans, add dependency relationships to integrate orphans into the graph, and consider whether very specific concepts should be merged into broader ones. Acceptable orphans include advanced capstone topics, specialized optional topics, or leaf concepts. Target less than 10% orphaned nodes.

questions.question: Claude Code keeps asking for permissions. How do I fix this?
questions.answer: The default permission model requires approval for every file operation. To allow skills to work autonomously, create '.claude/config.json' in your project with permissions allowing Skill(*), Bash(*:*), and FileSystem(read:./**/*.*,write:./**/*.*). Security note: only use permissive settings in Git-tracked directories where you can review and revert changes. Never use allow: ['*'] outside controlled environments. After creating the config, restart Claude Code to apply permissions.

questions.question: How do I fix module not found errors when running Python scripts?
questions.answer: Python 'module not found' errors typically mean missing dependencies. Check Python version (scripts require Python 3.x) with 'python --version'. Install required packages if needed with 'pip install pandas numpy'. Run from correct directory - scripts expect to be run from 'docs/learning-graph/' with 'cd docs/learning-graph' then 'python analyze-graph.py learning-graph.csv quality-metrics.md'. Most basic scripts use only Python standard library. If you encounter import errors, check the script's requirements or install packages individually.

questions.question: Why isn't my new page showing up in the MkDocs navigation?
questions.answer: MkDocs only displays pages explicitly listed in the 'nav:' section of 'mkdocs.yml'. After creating any new markdown file, open 'mkdocs.yml', find the appropriate section in 'nav:', add your new page with label and path, then save and rebuild with 'mkdocs serve' to test locally. Note that files not in 'nav:' are still built and accessible by direct URL, but won't appear in menus or navigation.

questions.question: My learning graph quality score is low. How do I improve it?
questions.answer: Low quality scores (below 70/100) indicate structural or balance issues. Check the quality metrics report for specific problems. For circular dependencies (mandatory fix), run 'analyze-graph.py' to identify cycles and break cycles by removing or reordering dependencies. For low connectivity (less than 2 avg dependencies), add more prerequisite relationships and connect isolated concepts to the main graph. For taxonomy imbalance (over 30% in one category), review over-represented categories and recategorize concepts for better distribution. For too many orphaned nodes (over 20%), add dependencies for terminal concepts and merge overly specific concepts.

questions.question: How do I handle Claude token limits during content generation?
questions.answer: Claude Pro accounts have token limits within 4-hour usage windows. For long textbook generation sessions, use these strategies to optimize usage: generate content incrementally (create 1-2 chapters at a time rather than entire textbook), use targeted skills (invoke specific skills like glossary or FAQ rather than the full intelligent-textbook workflow), split large files (break chapter content into smaller sections if hitting limits), monitor usage (track how many skills you've run in the current window), and plan generation sessions (space intensive tasks across multiple days). If you hit limits, wait for the 4-hour window to reset, then continue.

questions.question: Why is my MicroSim not displaying correctly?
questions.answer: Common MicroSim display issues and solutions include: for blank iframe, check file path in iframe src (should be relative like '../../sims/[name]/main.html'), verify 'main.html' exists in correct location, and open browser console for JavaScript errors. For p5.js not loading, ensure p5.js CDN link is in 'main.html'. For layout issues, adjust iframe width/height attributes, check canvas size in 'createCanvas(width, height)', and test standalone 'main.html' file directly in browser. For controls not working, verify slider/button event handlers are properly attached and check browser console for JavaScript errors.

questions.question: How do I fix Git merge conflicts in markdown files?
questions.answer: Git merge conflicts occur when the same lines are modified in different branches. For markdown content, identify conflicts with 'git status' (shows conflicted files), open conflicted file and look for conflict markers (<<<<<<< HEAD, =======, >>>>>>> branch-name), resolve manually by deciding which content to keep (or combine both) and removing conflict markers, then complete merge with 'git add resolved-file.md' and 'git commit -m "Resolved merge conflict in chapter 3"'. Prevention: coordinate with collaborators on which files to edit, or work on different chapters/sections simultaneously.

questions.question: What's the recommended workflow for creating a new intelligent textbook?
questions.answer: The optimal workflow follows the intelligent-textbook skill's 12-step process across five phases: Phase 1 Foundation (develop course description, validate with analyzer, generate learning graph), Phase 2 Structure (validate learning graph quality, add taxonomy, create chapter structure), Phase 3 Content (generate chapter content, create glossary, build MicroSims), Phase 4 Resources (generate FAQ and quizzes), and Phase 5 Publish (deploy to GitHub Pages). This sequence ensures each step builds on previous work.

questions.question: How should I structure chapters in my textbook?
questions.answer: Effective chapter structure follows pedagogical best practices and learning graph dependencies. Chapter components include introduction (overview and learning objectives), prerequisites (required prior knowledge with links), core content (3-7 major sections), worked examples (2-3 detailed examples), practice exercises (5-8 exercises at varying Bloom's levels), summary (key takeaways as bullet list), and further reading (optional advanced resources). Each chapter should address 10-20 related concepts from the learning graph, respecting dependency order. Target 2,000-5,000 words per chapter for comprehensive coverage without overwhelming readers. The book-chapter-generator skill automatically creates chapter structure based on learning graph dependencies.

questions.question: When should I use skills vs. manual content creation?
questions.answer: Use skills for repetitive structure (glossaries, FAQs, quiz questions that follow templates), data processing (learning graph validation, taxonomy categorization), initial drafts (chapter outlines, concept lists, dependency mapping), boilerplate code (MicroSim templates, HTML structures), and quality validation (running quality checks and generating reports). Use manual creation for creative examples (domain-specific scenarios and analogies), nuanced explanations (complex concepts requiring expert insight), custom visualizations (unique diagrams tailored to specific content), refinement (editing AI-generated content for tone, accuracy, and clarity), and domain expertise (subject matter that requires specialized knowledge). Best approach: use skills for 70% of structural work, then manually refine and customize the remaining 30% to add personality, domain expertise, and polish.

questions.question: How do I maintain consistent terminology across chapters?
questions.answer: Consistent terminology improves readability and comprehension. Best practices include using the glossary as single source of truth (generate glossary early, reference glossary terms when writing content, use exact glossary phrasing in all chapters), linking to glossary on first use, creating a style guide documenting conventions for capitalization, abbreviations, and technical terms, and using search and replace before finalizing to search for variant terms and standardize. The add-glossary-links skill can automatically link terms to glossary definitions throughout your textbook.

questions.question: How do I ensure my content addresses all Bloom's Taxonomy levels?
questions.answer: Well-designed educational content distributes learning activities across all six cognitive levels: Remember 20% (define terms, list components, recall facts), Understand 30% (explain concepts, summarize processes), Apply 25% (use procedures, solve problems), Analyze 15% (compare, categorize, examine relationships), Evaluate 7% (critique, judge, assess), and Create 3% (design, develop, construct). The quiz-generator skill automatically distributes questions across Bloom's levels.

questions.question: What's the best way to organize MicroSims in my textbook?
questions.answer: Effective MicroSim organization enhances learning without overwhelming students. Location strategy: store all MicroSims in 'docs/sims/[name]/' for centralization, create a MicroSim index page listing all simulations, and embed MicroSims in relevant chapter sections using iframes. Integration approach options include inline (embed within chapter content where concept is introduced), supplementary (link to MicroSim page for optional exploration), and progressive (start with simple sims in early chapters, advance complexity later). Each MicroSim should have learning objective, instructions for interacting with controls, questions to guide exploration, and connection to chapter concepts. Use descriptive, kebab-case names like 'concept-dependency-graph', 'bloom-taxonomy-levels', or 'random-walk-simulation'.

questions.question: How often should I update my learning graph?
questions.answer: Learning graphs should evolve with your course content. During initial development, generate comprehensive 200-concept graph before content creation. During content creation, update as you discover missing concepts that should be included, over-granular concepts that should be merged, or incorrect dependency relationships. After course delivery, revise based on student feedback about prerequisite gaps, assessment data showing struggling points, and new topics to add or outdated content to remove. Use Git to track learning graph changes with semantic versioning in commit messages. Update the quality metrics report and JSON visualization after each revision.

questions.question: Should I generate all content at once or incrementally?
questions.answer: Incremental generation is strongly recommended. Advantages include token management (avoids hitting Claude usage limits), quality control (review and refine each chapter before moving forward), iteration (improve prompts based on early results), flexibility (adjust structure or approach mid-project), and reduced risk (smaller changes are easier to debug and revert). Recommended pace: Week 1 (course description, learning graph, chapter structure), Week 2-3 (Chapters 1-4 foundational content), Week 4-5 (Chapters 5-8 core concepts), Week 6-7 (Chapters 9-12 advanced topics), Week 8 (resources, MicroSims, final review). Exception: generate glossary early (after learning graph) so you can reference consistent terminology throughout content creation.

questions.question: How do I credit AI-generated content appropriately?
questions.answer: Transparency about AI-assisted content is both ethical and increasingly expected. In textbook front matter (preface or about page), include a statement like 'This textbook was created using Claude AI and Claude Skills for automated content generation, with human review and refinement by [Author Name]. All content has been validated for accuracy.' In individual sections (optional, for transparency), add admonitions for AI-generated sections. In repository, include skill names and versions in commit messages and document the generation workflow in README. For licensing, choose appropriate licenses (CC BY, MIT, Apache 2.0) that allow derivative works. This course uses Apache 2.0 for skills, allowing commercial and academic use with attribution.

questions.question: What are best practices for version control with textbook content?
questions.answer: Git best practices for educational content include branching strategy (main for stable published content, develop for work-in-progress chapters, feature/chapter-N for individual chapter branches), commit practices (commit after completing each chapter, write descriptive messages, commit generated files for reproducibility), tracking all markdown content, configuration files, learning graph CSV and validation reports, and MicroSim HTML/JavaScript files. Ignore 'site/' (MkDocs build output), '.DS_Store' (Mac system files), and '__pycache__/' (Python cache) in .gitignore. For collaboration, use pull requests for major content changes, allowing review before merging.

questions.question: How can I customize the intelligent-textbook skill workflow?
questions.answer: The intelligent-textbook skill follows a 12-step workflow defined in its SKILL.md file. To customize, use Method 1 (modify SKILL.md directly by navigating to '~/.claude/skills/intelligent-textbook/', editing SKILL.md to change steps, add new processes, or adjust parameters, then saving and reinvoking the skill), Method 2 (create project-specific variant by copying skill to '.claude/skills/' in your project, renaming it, modifying workflow for your specific needs, and updating skill name in YAML frontmatter), or Method 3 (invoke steps manually by running individual component skills in custom order instead of the full intelligent-textbook skill). This gives maximum control over the process.

questions.question: How do I create a custom skill for my specific domain?
questions.answer: Creating domain-specific skills extends the intelligent textbook framework. Step 1: Plan the skill by defining the specific task it automates, identifying required inputs and expected outputs, and listing the Claude Code tools needed. Step 2: Create skill structure with 'mkdir -p ~/.claude/skills/my-custom-skill'. Step 3: Write SKILL.md with YAML frontmatter including name, description, license, and allowed-tools, followed by skill instructions with purpose and workflow steps. Step 4: Test and refine by invoking with '/skill my-custom-skill' and iterating based on results.

questions.question: Can I integrate Claude Skills with Learning Management Systems?
questions.answer: While Claude Skills primarily generate static content, LMS integration is possible through several approaches: SCORM export (convert MkDocs content to SCORM packages for LMS import, requires additional tooling), xAPI integration (add Experience API tracking to MicroSims and quizzes to send learner data to LRS Learning Record Store), direct embedding (host MkDocs site and embed pages as iframes in LMS), content export (use generated markdown as source content, then manually import to LMS), and API integration (advanced users can develop custom skills that directly interface with LMS APIs like Canvas or Moodle). The course mentions xAPI support in Level 3-4 intelligent textbooks for tracking learner interactions. Full LMS integration requires additional development beyond the core skills.

questions.question: How do I optimize Claude usage for large textbook projects?
questions.answer: Strategies to minimize token usage while maintaining quality include content generation optimization (generate chapter outlines first then expand sections incrementally, use targeted skills rather than regenerating entire chapters, cache frequently referenced content locally), skill efficiency (review skill YAML frontmatter to ensure allowed-tools is minimal, use Haiku model for simple tasks vs. Sonnet for complex content, batch similar operations), workflow optimization (complete structural work before content generation, manually create examples and domain-specific content rather than generating with AI, use version control to avoid regenerating content after mistakes), and token budgeting (estimate token costs before starting, space intensive generation sessions across days to stay within limits, prioritize core chapters and defer optional content).

questions.question: What's the future roadmap for intelligent textbook skills?
questions.answer: While the course focuses on current Level 2-3 capabilities, future developments include Level 4 Adaptive Content (skills that generate multiple content versions for different learning styles, personalized learning pathways based on assessment performance, adaptive difficulty adjustment in exercises and MicroSims), Level 5 AI Personalization (integration with conversational AI tutors for real-time help, intelligent question answering using RAG over textbook content, automated formative assessment and feedback), enhanced skills (automated citation and reference management, video script generation for supplementary materials, advanced data visualization, accessibility auditing and remediation), and platform evolution (cloud-based skill marketplaces, collaborative multi-author workflows, analytics dashboards for content quality). These capabilities are emerging areas of research. Contributing to the claude-skills repository helps drive this evolution.

questions.question: How can I contribute new skills to the repository?
questions.answer: The claude-skills repository welcomes community contributions. The contribution process involves forking the repository on GitHub, creating a new skill in 'skills/your-skill-name/', writing comprehensive SKILL.md with clear workflow instructions, adding supporting files (Python scripts, templates, docs), testing thoroughly with sample textbook projects, documenting in skill-descriptions/ with example usage, and submitting a pull request with description of skill purpose and testing. Quality standards include following ISO 11179 for any definitions, including quality validation where applicable, providing example outputs, using Apache 2.0 license for consistency, and writing clear, actionable workflow steps. Skill ideas needed include domain-specific content generators, advanced visualization tools, accessibility checkers, citation and bibliography generators, and interactive assessment tools.
